body:
Hello,
I wanted to work on eslint and this seemed like a 'good first issue' to pick up. 

**My findings:**
I dug a bit deeper and found that the parser used by eslint(espree using acorn) is throwing this error in strict mode.

Specifically the error is thrown from here https://github.com/acornjs/acorn/blob/0d20f67b03e0784bdd18eb88e0f76e6a53043404/src/tokenize.js#L631

As for the fix there, this will not occur if you disable the 'strict' rule.

This is the file that i tried to replicate this issue
```js
"use strict";
function testIssue10031() {
    return "\033" + "postfix";
}
```
This threw me the error
```bash
  4:13  error  Parsing error: Octal literal in strict mode
```

If i disable the 'strict' rule, i get the proper rule suggestion for it
```js
/* eslint strict: 0 */
function testIssue10031() {
    return "\033" + "postfix";
}
```
```bash
  2:1   error  Missing JSDoc comment                          require-jsdoc
  2:10  error  'testIssue10031' is defined but never used     no-unused-vars
  3:12  error  Don't use octal: '\033'. Use '\u....' instead  no-octal-escape
  3:19  error  Unexpected string concatenation of literals    no-useless-concat
```

As eslint, i gather reports parse errors as also eslint errors, how should i proceed here? Should this be considered as a bug to be fixed?

@MuraliNunna Thanks for looking into this! You're correct that ESLint just catches parser errors and reports them as linting errors. However, I think there are a few issues with the test code that you're using, which are preventing it from being a good demonstration of this issue.

* The test code is running in strict mode, due to the `"use strict"` directive at the top. However, using octal escape sequences is a syntax error in strict mode, regardless of whether it's in a template literal, so the `prefer-template` rule never runs in that case.
* The test code is concatenating two string literals (`"\033"` and `"postfix"`). However, the `prefer-template` rule only reports an error when concatenating a string literal with something other than a string literal (e.g. a variable).

Have you tried using the example code and configuration that were provided in the original issue? I think if the source file only contains `'\033' + foo` (with nothing else), and only the `prefer-template` rule is enabled, it will be easier to trigger this bug.
@MuraliNunna I figured you stopped working on this?

issue.title: Fix: do not autofix octal escape sequence (fixes #10031)

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->

**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**

[ ] Documentation update
[X] Bug fix ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/master/templates/bug-report.md))
[ ] New rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/master/templates/rule-proposal.md))
[ ] Changes an existing rule ([template](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/eslint/eslint/master/templates/rule-change-proposal.md))
[ ] Add autofixing to a rule
[ ] Add a CLI option
[ ] Add something to the core
[ ] Other, please explain:

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->
https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/10031
<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**
Added a check for octal escape sequences in binary expressions. The```prefer-template``` rule does not attempt to fix binary expressions that contain octal escape sequences, and returns a ```null``` fixer object if this is the case.

Also added a test that ensures that binary expressions with octal escape sequences are not auto fixed.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

body: @malcolmsgroves Apologies for the late reply. I wasn't able to look into the issue after my initial comment. I should have at least put out a comment that i was not working on it. Thanks for the fix anyways.
